The thermal conduction time is sufficiently longer than typical slow oscillation periods in the range of temperatures from ∼1 to 5 MK (from a few to a few tens of minutes), which makes the effect of the thermal conduction on the slow wave weak in this temperature range. In a hotter plasma, from ∼5 to 12 MK, τcond is roughly comparable with the slow oscillation period, indicating high efficiency of the wave damping by thermal conduction. For temperatures above 12 MK, τcond becomes substantially shorter than the slow oscillation period, implying that the thermal conduction rapidly smooths out any temperature gradient along the field and thus making the slow wave nearly isothermal. In the lower thermal conduction limit, the conductive damping time of slow waves, 

, decreases with temperature down to some value, after which the wave dynamics approaches the isothermal regime and therefore becomes independent of the thermal conductivity (e.g., Porter et al. 1994, Krishna Prasad et al. 2019). The existence of the isothermal regime indicates the importance of additional dissipative mechanisms for slow modes in the corona. It could be viscous damping (Owen et al. 2009, Wang et al. 2018), longitudinal nonuniformity (De Moortel & Hood 2004, Konkol et al. 2010), nonlinear damping (e.g., Verwichte et al. 2008, Ruderman 2013), mode coupling (De Moortel et al. 2004), or damping by the misbalance between coronal heating and radiative cooling processes (Nakariakov et al. 2017, Kolotkov et al. 2019). A relative efficiency of these damping mechanisms in specific coronal conditions needs to be revealed.

Magnetohydrodynamic_3.title: Magnetohydrodynamic Waves in the Solar Corona
Magnetohydrodynamic_3.question: What are the typical observational characteristics of propagating slow magnetoacoustic waves in the solar corona, and how are they detected?
Magnetohydrodynamic_3.text:
Compressive propagating coronal slow waves are usually associated with quasi-periodic EUV and soft X-ray intensity perturbations that move upward along field-aligned plasma nonuniformities. They are observed, in particular, with the high-resolution imaging telescopes. These propagating quasi-periodic disturbances typically have small amplitudes of a few percent of the background intensity, with periods in the range of 2–10 min and propagation speeds of ∼70–235 km s−1, which are comparable with the local sound speed. These waves are observed to decay quickly with height and with the decay length of a few tens of millions of meters. Routine observations demonstrated omnipresence of this phenomenon, occurring in both the plume and interplume regions in polar coronal holes (e.g., Gupta et al. 2010), legs of long fan-like loops in active regions (see 
Figure 4
 and Yuan & Nakariakov 2012), and also in plume-like structures in equatorial coronal holes and quiet Sun regions (e.g., Tian et al. 2011, Krishna Prasad et al. 2012b). These waves could be also detected spectroscopically, as Doppler shift variations and emission enhancements in the blue wing of the emission line (e.g., Verwichte et al. 2010), manifesting the in-phase behavior of the velocity and density perturbations. For comprehensive reviews of earlier observational results on the detection of propagating slow waves in coronal loops and holes, readers are referred to, e.g., De Moortel (2009) and Banerjee et al. (2011). Discussion of an alternative interpretation for the propagating EUV disturbances, in terms of quasi-periodic upflows, and its constructive criticism based on the comparison to the wave-related explanation are given by Wang (2016).

1511.05853_2.title: The Magellanic Stream: Circumnavigating the Galaxy
1511.05853_2.question: How has our understanding of the Magellanic Stream's neutral gas structure evolved with improvements in radio telescope technology?
1511.05853_2.text:
The Stream was discovered and characterized in Hi 21-cm emission, so we have a detailed understanding of the spatial structure and morphology of the neutral gas. Our knowledge has progressed hand in hand with successive generations of radio telescopes. Major 21-cm surveys covering parts or all of the Stream include those by Mathewson et al. (1974, 1977), Bajaja et al. (1985), Hulsbosch & Wakker (1988), Morras et al. (2000), Lockman et al. (2002), Putman et al. (2003b), Brüns et al. (2005), Kalberla et al. (2005), Stanimirović et al. (2008), Nidever et al. (2008, 2010), and McClure-Griffiths et al. (2009). The full size of the Stream can be seen in 
Figure 1
 (Nidever et al. 2010), which shows its extent on an all-sky map.

1511.05853_3.title: The Magellanic Stream: Circumnavigating the Galaxy
1511.05853_3.question: How have observations of different tracers improved our knowledge of the LMC's internal kinematics over the past two decades?
1511.05853_3.text: The dynamics, structure, and star-formation history of the LMC have long been interpreted in the context of its proximity to both the MW and its dwarf-galaxy companion, the SMC. This has allowed for detailed and thorough analyses of its structure and kinematics, with much work in the past decade based on measuring the photometry and kinematics of large samples of individual stars, as well as on deep star counts to measure the true extent of the LMC. Our knowledge of the internal kinematics of the LMC has improved over the past two decades, with different observational tracers covering different components of the Magellanic System. This includes kinematic measurements of Hi gas (Kim et al. 1998, Staveley-Smith et al. 2003), star clusters (Grocholski et al. 2006), and stars (Prevot et al. 1985, Kunkel et al. 1997, van der Marel et al. 2002, Massey & Olsen 2003, Olsen & Massey 2007, Olsen et al. 2011).

Evidence_1.title: Evidence for Initial Mass Function Variation in Massive Early-Type Galaxies
Evidence_1.question: What physical processes have been proposed to explain the shape of the initial mass function (IMF), and how do observations constrain its environmental dependence?
Evidence_1.text: To date, there is no complete theoretical understanding of the origin of the whole shape of the IMF, including the characteristic mass of the break or turnover. A wide range of physical processes has been invoked as being responsible for shaping the IMF during star formation, including turbulent fragmentation, magnetic fields, and radiative feedback from massive protostars (e.g., Padoan & Nordlund 2002, Bonnell et al. 2006, Krumholz 2006, Hennebelle & Chabrier 2008, Bate 2009, Hopkins 2012). Some of these conjectures favor an IMF that depends on the environment in which star formation proceeds: e.g., those where the characteristic mass scale is set by the Jeans mass (or its equivalent in turbulent models), which in turn depends on the ambient density, temperature, etc. Extensive efforts to measure the IMF in different star-forming regions in the MW have not found compelling evidence for systematic dependence on such properties (e.g., Bastian et al. 2010), although localized deviations from the standard form do seem to be present in a few regions (e.g., Luhman 2004, Lu et al. 2013). Hence much of the theoretical modeling effort cited above was aimed at accounting for the apparent near-universality of the IMF.

Evidence_2.title: Evidence for Initial Mass Function Variation in Massive Early-Type Galaxies
Evidence_2.question: How do strong gravitational lensing measurements of low-redshift elliptical galaxies constrain their stellar initial mass functions?
Evidence_2.text:
For many years, the only known low-redshift strong-lens system was Q2237+0305, the Einstein Cross (Huchra et al. 1985). In this case, the lensing galaxy is a barred spiral with σ ≈ 165 km s−1, at z = 0.038, and analysis yields a total Einstein-aperture M/L that is too small to be consistent with a Salpeter or heavier IMF (Ferreras et al. 2010), even assuming no contribution from DM. Smith et al. (2005) discovered the first low-redshift elliptical galaxy known to act as a strong lens. ESO325–G004, at z = 0.034, images a background galaxy into a partial Einstein ring, providing a very robust measurement of the mass projected inside a radius of 1.9 kpc (∼0.25 R
eff). With a high velocity dispersion (σ ∼300 km s−1), absence of any apparent ongoing star formation, negligible rotation, and α-enhanced abundance pattern, this galaxy is typical of the objects found in other studies to have a (bottom-)heavy IMF. However, Smith & Lucey (2013) showed that the lensing mass implies Ψ to be consistent with a MW IMF (αlens = 1.04 ± 0.15). They assumed a theoretically motivated estimate for the projected DM contribution, but this is a small correction (15%) due to the small projected Einstein radius, and even attributing all mass to the stars yields a sub-Salpeter α factor. Three further low-z early-type lens galaxies have since been discovered (Smith et al. 2015, Collier et al. 2018). After corrections for the likely projected DM content, based on cosmological simulations, all of these galaxies have α consistent with a MW IMF, on ∼2-kpc scales. Efforts are underway to enlarge the samples of low-redshift strong lenses (Talbot et al. 2018, Collier et al. 2020). The approach can be augmented with upper limits on α from galaxies with close-projected but singly imaged background galaxies, when unambiguous limits on counter-images can be established (Smith et al. 2018).

Evidence_3.title: Evidence for Initial Mass Function Variation in Massive Early-Type Galaxies
Evidence_3.question: How does the two-phase formation scenario for massive early-type galaxies potentially explain observed radial variations in their initial mass functions?
Evidence_3.text:
CONNECTION TO THE TWO-PHASE GALAXY FORMATION SCENARIOEvidence from both observations and simulations seems to support a two-phase scenario for the formation of massive ETGs (Oser et al. 2010). In this picture, an early phase of in situ star formation (Barro et al. 2013) leads to a population of initially compact (1–2 kpc) but massive (∼1011 M⊙) quiescent galaxies at z


 1.5 (Trujillo et al. 2006), which later grow by accreting stars that formed elsewhere, through minor mergers (Belli et al. 2014). The similarity in size-scale with the radial extent of the IMF variations in massive ETGs (

2 kpc, e.g., van Dokkum et al. 2017, La Barbera et al. 2019) tempts speculation that the IMF signal is linked specifically to the surviving stars from the in situ formation phase, which are thought still to dominate the innermost regions (<0.1 R
eff) of their descendent galaxies at z = 0 (e.g., Rodriguez-Gomez et al. 2016). This picture finds support in some rare relic galaxies at low redshift that are thought to have suffered little accretion after the initial phase, and which indeed seem to exhibit bottom-heavy IMFs at all radii (Ferré-Mateu et al. 2017).
